content: hey everyone why lock here recently we
did easier Tavern tiles ways to cut corners on my old tavern tiles from
episode 10 and at the end of that video you saw a whole bunch of new scatter
train and clip ons and goodies so in this episode multiple projects in one
here's a bunch of stuff to decorate your tavern with let's start out with doors
now I did these way back in episode 5 but the video quality was terrible and I
had no idea what I was doing so here's a quick review with modern production
values popsicle sticks use a chisel or a screwdriver or anything with a hard
metal corner and carve wavy lines in it like this to create a green base it was
solid black just cheap acrylic craft paint then over brush with burnt umber
against the green about 80% coverage then with terracotta dry brush about 50%
coverage and finally a dry brush with honey brown again maybe 50% so here they
are ready to go make a lot at once build a stockpile for yourself later projects
that'll be handy that kind of thing anyway chop these into two inch lengths
you should get two of them per stick so from double corrugated cardboard cut
yourself a rectangle that is one in an eighth by one-and-a-half inches tall
remember we use double corrugated because it's a quarter inch thick which
is exactly how thick our tile walls are so we can make clip-ons just last
episode we talked about tavern tiles so go check that out if you haven't already
so will hot glue those planks to the rectangle like this and you can see that
now there's a nice half-inch gap at the bottom that's the clip and then with
some thin cardstock cut out a strip of corrugation cladding and hot glue it on
this is the same stuff we talked about last time in episode 112 put a knob or a
door pull on there if you want I'm not worried about it
skipping it and along that same line a clip on window we already did this back
in episode 66 so I'll just put a card on the screen for reference now this was a
fun one let's make a hearth foam board this is called ready board and it's
available at Dollar Tree it's good because the paper peels really easily
cut out a two and a half inch square and peel the paper off one side texturize it
with cobblestone using method of your choice maybe check out
episode 10 for this I did I decided to take a shortcut and use a green stuff
roller lots of pressure then a rectangle three-quarter inch by two and a half
inch again peel the paper from one side and texturize it hot glue it to the
bottom of the square like you see here making sure it's flush then with some
cereal box or ideally chipboard which I'm going to use I cut out a 1 inch by 2
and 1/2 inch rectangle and glue it to the bottom dish to help bind everything
together and make that base real solid by the way if you're new to the channel
this is graphics medium chipboard awesome stuff there's an amazon link in
the description below doesn't cost you an extra cent but if you use that link I
get a small kickback totally free way to support the channel if you like and now
from double corrugated we do the middle slab so this is going to be 2 by 2 and a
half for tips on precision cutting revisit episode 111 and attach this to
the back of the foam square you can see the beginnings of the clip on at this
point make sure you align it to the top and not the bottom then I cut a 3/4 inch
strip of foam board peeled the paper and texturized it from that I chopped out 4
sections each of them one and 1/8 of an inch long peel the paper from the
remaining side and glue two of them together back-to-back with a thin layer
of white glue if you have access to thicker foam of some kind just use that
I'm assuming that you don't so this is sort of a way to fabricate a thicker
slab if you don't have that anyways hot glue these onto the piece as shown
here's a wooden dowel from the craft store 3/8 inch thick it's either balsa
or basswood I don't remember but it's really soft and it can be cut with a
plain old crafting utility knife so I cut two lengths of two and a half inches
glue them together with white glue and then kind of rounded the edges and
texturize and painted this up with the usual wood scheme hot glue it on the
piece as you see here and then cut a second two and a half inch square of
foam and hot glue that to the back this completes the clip
then bass in black don't use spray-paint use acrylic a good dry brush with gray
very simple keep it light really work the paint off the brush before you start
applying it and take your time so let the dry brush build up slowly and here
it is with the wood done up just as we described earlier and corrugation
cladding hot glue to the outside decorate it however you like here's a
circular bead that works well as a shield so I glued that above the heart
in candles I literally use DM Scotty's candle method I'm not even gonna cover
it here because I didn't even iterate I followed his video to a tee so go and
watch that one I'll put a card on the screen for the fire itself same story
that's all DM Scottie so I'll put a card on the screen a keg super easy to
plastic bottle caps hot glue them together thin strip a card stock to
cover the seam prime it with rattle-can and paint it up I also glued together
some toothpicks to make a stand for it and what's a tavern without a bar I like
to keep this real simple couple slabs of double corrugated cardboard hot glued
together to make the core of it and then I had leftover wood veneers that we
prepared back in episode 112 cut some strips to cover up the cardboard and hot
glue it on there touch up the exposed edges of foam with dark brown and then
these wooden craft picks I just chopped some of them up paint them Brown and
glue them on very simple likewise for tables here's a wooden bit
from the craft store if you've been in Michaels or the like you've surely seen
this guy I'm going to cut out a piece of chipboard hot glue it on top and cover
the chipboard with wood veneer two minute craft and one more clip on a sign
for the front of the Tavern on the outside this begins like all of our
clip-on features he got double created in the middle sandwich with two larger
slabs of chipboard so I won't belabor the point again if you're new here I
have a playlist dedicated to clip-on features that you can check out then I
painted the foundation and applied corrugation cladding using the same
colors and materials as we did back in episode 112 hot glue a popsicle stick to
the middle and use more of that wooden dowel one length sticking straight out
and then like a support piece cut at 45 degrees all of this just hot glued on
the sign itself requires a bit of finesse unwind a paper clip jam it into
the dowel in two spots it's really soft so you'll be able to do this easily then
with needle nose pliers twist it into a small hook and cut off that hook secure
it in the hole with superglue make sure both hooks are oriented in the same
direction I find that these plastic coated paper clips work really good and
for the sign a little rectangle of chipboard sliced out some channels like
this and made two more hooks and they made the sign itself in
Photoshop or Microsoft Word and just printed it glued one of them to one side
insert the hooks in those channels with a dab of superglue and secure the other
side with the other print out so that hangs on there nicely this whole thing
is probably more trouble than it's worth but the small advantage is that you can
make different signs and swap them out if you want to and we're about to go to
the table to see the final product but real quick some reminders if you like
what you're about to see please don't hesitate to hit that like button

surprised by how well it came out sometimes I sit down and think I want to
do a new clip-on feature I go to my list of things that you guys have suggested
in live streams and stuff and Hart kept showing up so I just took a shot this
usually I build something then I rebuild it while I'm shooting it this one I was
able to do which is very organic came out very nice I'm happy with it I often
get asked how many tiles should I make and that's gonna vary on the style that
you're using and the designs of your dungeons or your rooms or whatever for
taverns the one you see in front of you now these are the ones that I've made I
don't really plan on making more these should be enough to set any scene that I
would want to don't really plan on any dungeon sized tavern so these whatever
16 or so should be fine you know even though I use gridded tiles I usually run
grid lists I don't care much about the squares there are way to speed measure
and rough estimate distance in a dungeon that can matter from mechanical combat
stuff but in a tavern think about like stealth and intrigue and can you hear
something that's that far away so Tavern tiles are useful for that if you liked
this particular project here's two more that you should go check out right now
also enjoy this month's community showcase and don't forget to subscribe
